summary: This video is a quick guide to fashion history from the 1900s to the 1960s, showcasing different styles and trends for each decade. It covers the hourglass figure, defined waists, hemlines, silhouettes, and popular accessories of each era.
transcript: This is a quick guide to fashion history from the 1900s to the 1960s. First the 1900s. The 1900s. First: the 1900s. This decade had the extreme hourglass figure, large bust, and large hips. Simple white and colored blouses tucked into a long narrow skirt was the basic everyday look. The 1910s. The 1910s brought a much more natural silhouette, but the waist was definitely still defined. If you see an outfit with a ridiculous amount of lace and equally ridiculous sized hats then it's probably from the 1910s. For the 1920s, hemlines rose drastically. However, the defining factor of this decade of fashion was that there was no defined waist, as well as the iconic finger waves. 1930s. 1930s fashion was all about satin and ruffles. The silhouette was very natural and high waistlines as well. Puffy sleeves were popular. Hats were also always at a tilt. 1940s. Think of 1940s fashion as the original 1980s. Shoulder pads were in, and the overall daily look took more of a masculine approach. Women began to regularly wear pants, and long, Rita Hayworth inspired hair was popular. 1950s. Now the 1950s was the exact opposite. This decade was ultra feminine. The hourglass figure was back, and full skirts and bright colors was the staple of the decade. Hair was achieved using pin curls and was shorter than the 1940s. 1960s. Lastly, the 1960s was heavily inspired by the 1920s. This time, colors were even brighter, and skirts were even shorter. And the bigger the hair, the better. 1966. And the bigger the hair, the better.
